text: my name is Nicholas Negron and I'm a
professor uh at MIT in Cambridge
Massachusetts well one laptop per child
is is is based on the theories of
constructionism and those were founded
originally by Jean p in Geneva and more
contemporaneously with us at least uh by
a man named Seymour papert who was also
at MIT and Seymour made an observation
in
1968 that was very simple but very
profound and that is that if a child
writes a computer program that child is
engaged in the closest approximation we
can come to thinking about thinking and
what is sort of even more important is
is that when you write a computer
program it never works the first time so
you have to go through a stage called
debugging and the process of debugging
going and correcting the program and
then looking at the behavior and then
correcting it again and finally
iteratively getting to a working program
is in fact very close to learning about
learning and what Seymour observed back
in the late 60s and early 70s was that
we didn't really teach think thinking we
taught subjects and that we went through
school learning particular bodies of
knowledge but we never learned learning
itself and that was the the real
influence for one laptop per child
because in the 70s we started to work
with computers and children in New York
and other places and very sort of poor
districts this wasn't just in fancy
private schools and then in the early
80s we doing this in afca Africa and
Asia and and South America in very
remote rural parts of the world that was
the beginning and it all started with
constructionism it started with learning
learning and children being active
agents uh in their own
education well the laptop is designed to
be child Centric in in in a number of
very important ways um first of all
there simple properties because when we
say child we mean six to 12 years old we
really mean primary education um and as
soon as you have that you know age group
you have to make it pretty
indestructible it's you've got to be
able to drop it from six or seven feet
it's going to be stepped on it's going
to be carried in the rain and and so
it's gets subjective to treatment that
is more like military equipment than it
is office equipment so that's one aspect
of it which is a bit bit mundane but
it's certainly true another aspect is
you want it to work in the sunlight when

able to read books on it you want them
doesn't mean that they have to be in the
baking sun but your laptop and my laptop
really don't work Outdoors because the
screen technology just is not reflective
screen it's transmitted and and it gets
washed out very easily so we had to do
some again very pragmatic things make
the display what we call a dual mode
that it works both reflective and
transmissive and then there are other
aspects of it that have more to do with
the emphasis on collaboration so these
laptops talk to the neighboring laptops
and so there are these cute little ears
on them that are the antennas for Wi-Fi
but they're also antennas so that if you
had a room full or a neighborhood full
of let's say 50 laptops each one can
talk to the other and they can actually
relay messages so you can sort of daisy
chain to connect all of these laptops
together and the interface shows what
other kids are using it a little bit
like a cell phone or or some of the
so-called uh you know social media that
we have today where your buddy lists and

office machine it is really a children's
machine and was designed
has one from the very
beginning in in the world of computers
and and just devices in general the the
lifespan or the shelf life is is
relatively short uh just because
technology moves so fast and the costs
drop so quickly and the the power
whether it's computing power or memory
you know Rises uh very very quickly on
the other hand they self life isn't
quite as short as you know advertisers
and companies would want you to believe
there's there's a lot of uh life in
these machines that is beyond what's
advertised so we design them for a
five-year lifespan and that five years
drives us to do things which again
normal manufacturers don't do namely you
can charge and discharge our battery
about five to 10 times more often than
you can a normal battery because we
expect them to to be used a lot longer
and the evidence that this could be true
can be seen in automobiles you go to
developing countries today and you'll
find automobiles that you haven't seen
since your childhood and that's because
they really are valuable they're taken
care of they're repaired and when
something breaks they don't just buy a
new one they actually fix it and if the
if the product is no longer on the
market they make it and uh we think
these laptops would be treated uh that
way as well because the ones that we
have out at the moment the kids really
take care of them they love them dearly
they they sleep with them in almost
every case we have about
1.5 million of them in the field today
in 31 countries and I would guess that
50% of the kids that have them sleep
with their laptops and the little boys
get their sisters to make bags and
there's a whole ownership and and and
sort of a feeling towards these machines
which yes in five years they should get

advanced then but one doesn't
wait well perhaps the
the the most compelling piece of

have been doing experiments
uh for you know before the actual laptop

uh best we can tell all of those kids
are in school today still today eight

important because there is a belief that
